Literature Review: The study of drying drops of colloidal dispersions has evolved significantly since its inception in the nineteenth century, offering insights into the complex interplay of physical and chemical processes. This literature review delves into the multifaceted nature of these phenomena, focusing on the underlying principles and the diverse patterns they produce. The evaporation of sessile drops, a key area of interest, involves intricate dynamics of heat, mass, and momentum transfer, alongside colloidal and interfacial phenomena. Deegan et al. (1997) pioneered the understanding of the 'coffee ring' effect, demonstrating how particle deposition at the edge of a drying drop is driven by capillary flow induced by evaporation. This foundational work has spurred extensive research into evaporative patterns and the factors influencing them, such as particle size, shape, and interactions. Hu and Larson (2006) further elucidated the role of Marangoni flows in altering the deposition patterns, highlighting the importance of surface tension gradients. The complexity increases with the introduction of complex fluids, where the rheological properties of the dispersion significantly impact the drying process. Yunker et al. (2011) explored how the addition of surfactants can suppress the coffee ring effect, leading to more uniform deposition. This finding has implications for applications ranging from inkjet printing to the fabrication of thin films. The drying of drops in complex configurations, such as on patterned or flexible substrates, introduces additional variables into the system. Park and Moon (2006) investigated the influence of substrate wettability on the drying dynamics and pattern formation, revealing how surface properties can be engineered to control the final deposit morphology. Moreover, the role of environmental conditions, such as humidity and temperature, has been extensively studied. Shahidzadeh-Bonn et al. (2008) demonstrated how these factors can affect the evaporation rate and, consequently, the drying patterns. The interplay between evaporation-driven flows and colloidal interactions has also been a focus of recent research. Marin et al. (2011) provided insights into how particle aggregation and gelation can influence the drying process, leading to diverse structural outcomes. Additionally, the advent of advanced imaging and computational techniques has enabled a deeper understanding of the transient dynamics within drying drops. Li et al. (2017) utilized high-speed imaging to capture the intricate flow patterns and particle movements during evaporation. This technological advancement has opened new avenues for the precise control and manipulation of drying processes. In summary, the study of drying drops of colloidal dispersions encompasses a broad spectrum of scientific disciplines, offering rich insights into the fundamental principles governing these phenomena. The continuous evolution of this field, driven by both theoretical and experimental advancements, holds promise for the development of novel applications in materials science, biotechnology, and beyond.
